hFPHTKgG.title: Concentration-dependent switching of the mode of phase separation in ternary self-assembled monolayers of 2-mercaptoethane sulfonic acid, 2-aminoethanethiol and 1-dodecanethiol on Au(111)
hFPHTKgG.abstract: Unusually strong apparent surface activity of the pair of 2-mercaptoethane sulfonic acid (MES) and 2-aminoethanethiol (AET) in forming a phase-separated ternary self-assembled monolayer (SAM) composed of MES, AET, and 1-dodecanethiol (DDeT) has been investigated with changing the conditions for preparing the SAM by coadsorption of the thiols from an ethanolic solution. When the total concentration of the thiols, c total , is 1 × 10 −3 mol dm −3 or higher, the MES–AET pair forms electrostatically stabilized domains from an early stage of the adsorption after the immersion of a gold substrate in the bathing ethanol solution. The total area of the MES–AET domains does not change with time for longer immersion. The adsorption of DDeT is significantly weaker than the MES–AET pair under such conditions, despite the fact that the intrinsic surface activity of DDeT is greater than those of MES and AET. DDeT-rich islands of typically a few nanometer across spread in the SAM and the size and the distribution of the islands are invariant over a week. In contrast, when c total is lower than 0.1 × 10 −3 mol dm −3 , the adsorptivity of DDeT is stronger than that of the MES–AET pair, and MES and AET initially adsorbed are gradually replaced with DDeT at longer immersion time. This switching of the mode of phase separation with the change in c total suggests the crucial roles of the electrostatic interaction of MES and AET in the course of the formation of the SAM and of the hydrophilic barrier formed on the domains to prevent the replacement by hydrophobic DDeT molecules. Keywords 2-Mercaptoethane sulfonic acid 2-Aminoethanethiol 1-Dodecanethiol Ternary self-assembled monolayer Phase separation SAM Au(1 1 1) Reductive desorption Voltammetry 1 Introduction Phase-separated binary self-assembled monolayers (SAMs) of thiol derivatives on metal surface [1–17] have recently been utilized for a variety of studies in surface electrochemistry and surface engineering, for example, the wetting of SAM surface in relation to the nanometer-scale phase separation [18] , the rate of lateral diffusion of adsorbed alkanethiolates [19] , the formation of nanopores in the SAM [20,21] , the selective deposition of metals on specific domains [22,23] , the attachment of oligonucleotides [24] , the immobilization of enzymes on the specific domains of the SAM surface [25–27] and the controlled release of biological cells from the surface [28] . For wider application of SAMs with well defined surface properties in nanometer scale, further elucidation of the phase properties of binary and multi-components SAMs is of decisive importance. We recently reported that the ternary self-assembled monolayer (SAM) of 2-mercaptoethane sulfonic acid (MES), 2-aminoethanethiol (AET), and 1-dodecanethiol (DDeT) formed a phase-separated two types of domains, one consisting of DDeT and the other consisting of MES–AET pair [29] . Interestingly, the MES–AET pair showed apparently higher surface activity than DDeT; the equal surface coverages of the two types of the domains were achieved only when the concentration of the DDeT in the bathing ethanolic solution in preparing the SAM was twice as high as that of the MES–AET pair. The latter appears to be stabilized by the electrostatic interaction between the negatively charged MES and the protonated AET in the SAM [30] . This stronger adsorption of the MES–AET pair seemingly contradicts with the fact that the reductive desorption of the MES–AET domains takes place at a potential less negative than that of the DDeT domains [29] . Surprisingly, lowering the total concentration of the thiols in the ethanolic solution to 10 μmol dm −3 led to the recovery of the relative adsorptivity of DDeT with respect to that of the MES–AET pair [29] . This concentration dependence of the relative adsorptivity is opposite to the case of the formation of phase-separated binary SAMs composed of 3-mercapto-1-propanol (MPL) and 1-tetradecanethiol (TDT) [12] ; the adsorption of MPL having a less negative desorption potential is relatively enhanced with decreasing the total concentration of thiols. The dependence of the surface composition of SAMs on the total concentration of the thiols in the bathing solution suggests the importance of adsorption kinetics in forming the phase-separated domains. To elucidate the observed concentration-dependent surface activity of the MES–AET pair, we studied the time-dependence of the surface composition in the formation of the phase-separated SAMs of MES–AET–DDeT using cyclic voltammetry for the reductive desorption of adsorbed thiolates on Au(1 1 1) [31] , together with polarization-modulation FTIR reflective absorption spectroscopy (PMFTIRRAS), and scanning tunneling microscopy (STM). This paper describes the experimental results and our interpretation for the concentration-dependent switching of the surface activity of the MES–AET pair. 2 Experimental 2.1 Reagents Sodium 2-mercaptoethanesulfonate (NaMES) (Aldrich), 2-aminoethanethiol hydrochloride (AETHCl) (Aldrich) and DDeT (Wako Chem. Ind. Co.) were used without further purification. Water was purified with a Milli-Q system (Millipore Co.). All other chemicals were of reagent grade. The method of preparing gold-deposited mica having large Au(1 1 1) terraces on the surface has been described elsewhere [8] . Three-component thiol SAMs were formed on Au(1 1 1) in the ethanolic solution of NaMES, AETHCl and DDeT. The total thiol concentration in ethanol, c total , for preparing a SAM was varied from 1 × 10 −6 to 2 × 10 −3 mol dm −3 . The concentration of NaMES was always set to be equal to that of AETHCl. The ratio of the concentration of DDeT to the total concentration of NaMES and AETHCl in the solution, χ DDeT soln , was kept at 0.5, unless otherwise noted. Ternary SAMs composed of MES, AET and DDeT were prepared by immersing a gold substrate in the ethanolic solution of three thiols. 2.2 Measurements For cyclic voltammetry of the reductive desorption of SAMs, a gold-deposited mica coated with the SAM was mounted at the bottom of a cone-shaped cell by using an elastic O-ring [31] . The surface area of the electrode was calculated to be 0.126 cm 2 from the diameter of the O-ring. A solution of 0.5 mol dm −3 KOH in the cell was deaerated with Ar bubbling for 20 min. The potential, E , is referred to a Ag|AgCl (saturated KCl) electrode. All voltammetry measurements were made at the scan rate of 20 mV s −1 at 25 °C. PMFTIRRAS spectra were recorded with a Thermo-Mattson Infinity spectrometer equipped with a HgCdTe detector and a photoelastic modulator (Hinds, PEM-90) with the optical layout similar to that reported in the literature [32] . The signal was demodulated with a synchronous sampling demodulator (GWC Instruments). The differential reflectance was numerically converted to absorbance. All measurements were made in air at room temperature. Scanning tunneling microscopy (STM) images were acquired in air with a NanoScope III (Digital Instruments) using Pt 80 Ir 20 tips. The conductivity of the ethanolic solution of MES and AET was measured with a conductivity meter (Kyoto Electronics, CM-117) at room temperature. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Effect of the thiol concentration on surface coverages of MES–AET and DDeT Fig. 1 illustrates the effect of c total on the surface composition of phase-separated MES–AET–DDeT SAMs prepared by immersing the substrates in the ethanolic solution for at least 24 h. Curve ‘a’ is a cyclic voltammogram for the reductive desorption of the MES–AET–DDeT SAM prepared at c total = 1 × 10 −3 mol dm −3 and χ DDeT soln = 0.5 . Curves ‘b’, ‘c’, and d’ are voltammograms for the SAMs prepared similarly at c total = 5 × 10 −4 , 1 × 10 −5 , and 1 × 10 −6 mol dm −3 , respectively, at the same value of χ DDeT soln . In all cases, there appeared well-separated two peaks in the forward scans; the peak at E = −0.68 V corresponds to the desorption of the domains mainly composed of MES–AET and the peak at E = −1.05 V to the desorption of the DDeT-rich domains [29] . We hereafter call the peak at −0.68 V and that at −1.05 V, respectively, Peaks I and II. These voltammograms clearly illustrate the interesting dependence of the relative area of Peak I to that of Peak II on c total . When c total = 1 × 10 −3 mol dm −3 , the height as well as the area of Peak I is much larger than those of Peak II, that is, the adsorbed amount of MES–AET is much greater than that of DDeT. However, when c total = 1 × 10 −5 mol dm −3 (curve ‘c’), this order is reversed; the area of Peak II is much greater than that of Peak I. The same is true when c total = 1 × 10 −6 mol dm −3 (curve ‘d’) and 1 × 10 −4 mol dm −3 (data not shown). Then, there must be a critical value of c total above and below which the relative strength of the adsorption of DDeT and that of MES–AET is reversed. Fig. 2 shows the dependence of the peak area, Q , of Peak I on c total estimated from cyclic voltammograms for the substrates prepared at the immersion time of the substrate in the bathing solution, t imrs , being 24 h. There is a distinct jump in Q at around c total = 3 × 10 −4 mol dm −3 , showing the critical value of c total for the turnover of the prevailing type of the domains on the surface. Intrinsically, DDeT is more hydrophobic than MES and AET and hence is more surface-active. This is reflected in the difference in the position of E p in Fig. 1 . In this respect, the adsorption behavior when c total < 3 × 10 −4 mol dm −3 is consistent with the expectation based on thermodynamics. The inversion of the relative surface activity of MES–AET by changing c total suggests that the SAM is not in adsorption equilibrium, but the surface composition is kinetically determined [33] . To elucidate this point, we examined the time dependence of the surface coverage and the adsorbed state of the thiolates at different values of c total . 3.2 Time-dependence of the voltammetric response of SAMs prepared at c total = 1 × 10 −3 mol dm −3 The effect of the immersion time, t imrs , on the surface composition of the SAM was examined by cyclic voltammetry. Cyclic voltammograms for the reductive desorption of the SAMs prepared at c total = 1 × 10 −3 and 1 × 10 −5 mol dm −3 are displayed in Figs. 3 and 4 . Corresponding variations in the peak potential, E p , the area under the peak, Q , and the full width at half maximum, FWHM, for two major peaks around −0.7 and −1.05 V are plotted against t imrs in Figs. 5–7 . It can be seen in Fig. 3 that even at t imrs = 2 s, the narrow peak appeared at −0.68 V (curve ‘a’ in Fig. 3 ). E p and Q for this peak little varied with prolonged immersion up to 8 days (see also Figs. 5 a and 6 a). This unchanging shape of the peak at −0.68 V with t imrs implies that the MES–AET domains, whose size is large enough to give a peak at this potential, are formed even 2 s after the immersion of the substrate in the ethanolic solution; the MES–AET domains once formed are resistant against the replacement by DDeT present in the solution phase for more than a week. In the voltammogram at t imrs = 2 s, there is a small hump around E = −1.0 V, together with a broad peak at −0.85 V. With increasing t imrs this broad peak became less conspicuous and a new peak emerged at a more negative potential and shifted to −1.05 V. This peak indicates the formation of the DDeT-rich domains where DDeT molecules are packed with the tilt angle of the hydrocarbon chain with respect to the surface normal being about 30° [34–36] . This orientation was also confirmed by FTIR measurements (vide infra). The broader peak in the middle is likely to be ascribed to the desorption of less-ordered DDeT and possibly to microdomains of MES–AET that are not large enough to belong to the MES–AET domains giving the desorption peak at −0.68 V [8] . 3.3 Time-dependence of the voltammetric response of SAMs prepared at c total = 1 × 10 −5 mol dm −3 The lowering of c total dramatically changed the shape of a series of voltammograms. Fig. 4 shows voltammograms for the SAM prepared at several values of t imrs when c total = 1 × 10 −5 mol dm −3 . In contrast to the voltammograms in Fig. 3 , no sharp peak is seen at −0.68 V when t imrs = 2 s and 1 min (curves ‘a’ and ‘b’). A broad peak at less negative potential of about −0.55 V is discerned (curves ‘b’ and ‘c’). This peak grew with time. Simultaneously, the peak potential shifted toward the negative direction and the FWHM narrowed. When t imrs was longer than 5 h, the peak shifted to −0.7 V, that is, more negative than −0.68 V ( Fig. 5 a). The E p further shifted to the negative direction at larger values of t imrs with broadening of the peak. The FWHM narrowed with time ( Fig. 7 a), but was never as small as 25 mV. After 8 days of immersion, the peak around −0.7 V disappeared and a much broader peak appeared at −0.8 V (curve ‘i’ in Fig. 4 ). In some samples, even this broad peak was incognizable in the voltammograms (curve ‘j’ in Fig. 4 ). Eventually, MES–AET domains thus appear to be entirely replaced with DDeT, in contrast to the case shown in Fig. 3 . Peak II in Fig. 4 grew with t imrs . Concomitantly, the broad peak at −0.9 V seen at shorter t imrs values disappeared. At t imrs = 24 h, the area under the peak for the DDeT domains is more than twice as large as that of the MES–AET domains. This is distinctively different from the results in Fig. 3 , where the area for the DDeT domains is about one fifth of that for the MES–AET domains. The greater area of Peak II in Fig. 4 seems to go along with the difference in the hydrophobicity between the DDeT and the MES–AET pair. That is to say, the results in Fig. 4 are in accordance with intrinsic surface activities of DDeT and MES or AET and highlight the peculiarity in adsorption at c total = 1 × 10 −3 mol dm −3 . A further lowering of c total to 1 × 10 −6 mol dm −3 resulted in voltammograms whose basic features are similar to those observed in Fig. 4 (voltammograms not shown, see Figs. 5–7 ). From the comparison of CVs in Fig. 3 and those in Fig. 4 , one can see that the change in c total brings about a drastic change in the surface coverage of MES–AET and DDeT from the early stage of the formation of the SAM. 3.4 Variation of Peak I with t imrs To take a closer look at the dependence of the surface composition on t imrs , E p , Q , and FWHM for Peaks I and II are plotted against t imrs at four different values, 1 × 10 −6 , 1 × 10 −5 , 5 × 10 −4 , and 1 × 10 −3 mol dm −3 , in Figs. 5–7 . When c total is 1 × 10 −3 mol dm −3 or higher, E p is about −0.68 V and little varies with t imrs (see also Fig. 3 ). Correspondingly, both Q and FWHM values in Figs. 6 a and 7 a are almost constant at 70 μC cm −2 and 25 mV, respectively, over t imrs values from 2 s to 8 days ( Fig. 3 ). In the case of both MES–AET binary SAMs and single-component DDeT SAMs, the value of Q is about 100 μC cm −2 at the same scan rate [29,30] . The surface coverage of MES–AET domains in the present case is thus estimated to be 0.7, assuming that the charging current contribution to the peak area is the same for all these cases. The value of the FWHM, 25 mV, agrees with the value of the binary MES–AET SAMs [30] and indicates that the solubility of DDeT in the MES–AET domains is low, throughout the range of t imrs studied [29] . Lowering of c total greatly altered the position and the shape of Peak I ( Figs. 5 a, 6 a, and 7 a), as described above. When c total is 1 × 10 −5 mol dm −3 , the peak appeared at −0.58 V at t imrs = 2 s and gradually shifted to a negative potential with time, approaching to −0.71 V ( Fig. 5 a), which is about 30 mV more negative to the E p at higher values of c total . The FWHM at lower values of c total correspondingly decreased with t imrs . It might appear that such shifts in both E p and FWHM reflect the gradual formation of the MES–AET domains similar to those observed at higher c total values. However, the nature of Peak I at lower concentrations seems to be considerably different. When t imrs is 24 h, the FWHM at different c total values did not converge to a single value around 25 mV that is supposed to be a value for the desorption of neat MES–AET domains [30] . Rather, the FWHM depended on c total and was larger for smaller values of c total . This suggests that at lower c total values DDeT dissolved into MES–AET domains and the degree of the dissolution is greater at lower concentrations. When c total was further lowered to 1 × 10 −6 mol dm −3 , E p and Q basically varied in parallel with those at c total = 1 × 10 −5 mol dm −3 . However, the FWHM showed a sudden transition from 180 to 80 mV at t imrs = 40 min. This change is concurrent with a similar transitions of Q and FWHM of Peak II ( Fig. 6 b and 7 b). The transition of FWHM in Peak I is thus correlated with the transition in the DDeT-rich domains. This concurrent transitions of the two types of domains is suggestive of the mechanism of domain formation and will be further discussed below. 3.5 Variation of Peak II with t imrs The time-dependence of E p and of FWHM for the desorption of DDeT domains at different values of c total is shown in Figs. 5 b, 6 b, and 7 b. There is no significant dependence of E p on both t imrs and c total ( Fig. 6 a). On the other hand, the peak at small t imrs values was broad when c total was 1 × 10 −5 mol dm −3 , but the FWHM at different values of c total converged to about 35 mV. This convergence seems to be an indication that after sufficient time the DDeT-rich domains are in an adsorption equilibrium with the bathing solution, unlike the MES–AET domains. The value of 35 mV is considerably greater than 20 mV expected in the desorption of a SAM composed of alkanethiolates whose number of the methylene unit in the hydrocarbon chain is larger than 10 [37] . It is most likely that the broad FWHM in Fig. 7 b at longer t imrs is caused by the significant dissolution of MES and AET in the DDeT domains [29] . When c total was 1 × 10 −6 mol dm −3 , E p was only slightly more negative than those at higher values of c total . However, Figs. 6 b and 7 b show that Q and FWHM both undergo sharp transitions at t imrs = 40 min, in concurrence with FWHM of Peak I, as described above. The transition in Peak II obviously reflects the change in the orientation of DDeT molecules from a lying-down phase to a standing-up phase similar to single-component SAMs of alkanethiolates [38,39] . FTIR data shown below ( Fig. 8 ) confirm this supposition. An interesting fact here is that the concurrence of the transitions of Peaks I and II was seen when c total = 1 × 10 −6 mol dm −3 ; the cooperative change in DDeT-rich domains seems to induce the cooperative transition in MES–AET-rich domains. 3.6 Formation of DDeT-rich domains The time-dependence of CVs in Fig. 4 and that of the characteristic parameters in Figs. 5 b, 6 b and 7 b, show that DDeT-rich domains grew with t imrs when c total ⩽ 1 × 10 −5 mol dm −3 . At such lower c total values, DDeT molecules would have enough space to adsorb lying flat on the surface at short immersion times, as is the case of the formation of alkanethiol SAMs from gas phase [38] and that from a solution phase [39,40] . After time elapses, DDeT molecules stand up to form a densely packed DDeT domains, as seen in the dependence on t imrs of Q and FWHM in Figs. 5 b, 6 b, and 7 b at c total = 1 × 10 −6 and 1 × 10 −5 mol dm −3 . Corresponding changes in FTIR are shown in Figs. 8 B and C for c total = 1 × 10 −5 and 1 × 10 −6 mol dm −3 , respectively. At t imrs = 2 s, the peak at 2919 cm −1 ascribed to the CH 2 asymmetric stretching appeared for both substrates prepared at c total = 1 × 10 −6 and 1 × 10 −5 mol dm −3 . The ν as (CH 2 ) at this wavenumber is an indication that the alkyl group is lying flat on the surface [41] . With increasing t imrs , this peak shifted to 2927 cm −1 . Simultaneously, ν s (CH 3 ) at 2880 cm −1 and ν as (CH 3 ) at 2965 cm −1 , together with ν as (CH 2 ) at 2855 cm −1 grew, showing that the alkyl chain part is gradually standing up to form tightly packed DDeT-rich domains. The change in the orientation is in agreement with the process of forming single-component alkanethiol SAMs [38,42–44] . The growth of DDeT domains with t imrs at lower values of c total is confirmed in STM images in Figs. 9 and 10 for c total = 1 × 10 −5 and 1 × 10 −6 mol dm −3 , respectively. The phase transition of the DDeT domains at c total = 1 × 10 −6 mol dm −3 suggested from voltammograms is in fact seen as the growth of the domain size in a few tens min between t imrs = 30 min and 1 h ( Figs. 10 b and c). In contrast, the substrate formed at c total = 1 × 10 −3 mol dm −3 did not show a peak at ν as (CH 2 ) = 2919 and, instead, a peak appeared at 2927 cm −1 even at t imrs is 2 s (curve ‘a’ in Fig. 8 A). In curve ‘a’, ν s (CH 3 ) at 2880 cm −1 and ν as (CH 3 ) at 2965 cm −1 are also recognized. This suggests that even at t imrs = 2 s, a substantial number of adsorbed DDeT are standing up, despite the fact that the surface coverage of the DDeT domain is about one third, irrespective of the value of t imrs ( Fig. 6 b). The invariance corresponding to those of the shapes of both voltammograms and FTIR spectra at c total = 1 × 10 −3 mol dm −3 is observed as the invariant size and distribution of the DDeT domains over 8 days, as shown in Fig. 11 . The DDeT domains of less than 10 nm across are spread already at t imrs = 2 s and, amazingly, the size and its distribution are retained over 8 days. 3.7 Mechanism of the formation of MES–AET domains From the time-dependent behavior of phase-separated SAMs of MES–AET–DDeT ternary systems shown in Figs. 3–7 , it is clear that the concentration-dependent enhancement of the adsorption of MES–AET is anomalous. From experimental results above, two different modes of phase separation of MES–AET–DDeT SAMs are clearly distinguished. We call these two modes observed above and below c total = 0.3 × 10 −3 mol dm −3 PS-mode I and PS-mode II, respectively. When a gold surface is exposed to a solution containing MES, AET and DDeT, the probability of finding one of these thiols per unit area per unit time in the solution phase next to the surface must be the same at any value of c total , provided that no association between these adsorbates exists in the bathing solution. If all thiols reached at the surface adsorb on the surface according to this probability, the change in c total would not cause the change in the relative surface coverages of DDeT-rich domains and MES–AET-rich domains, at least when the surface coverage is small. A diffusion-limited adsorption of a surface-active substance i to a planar clean surface is proportional to the concentration of the adsorbate, c i , and to the square-root of its diffusion coefficient, D i [45] : (1) Γ i ( t ) = 2 D i t c i b π where Γ i ( t ) is the adsorbed amount of i at time t . When c total = 1 × 10 −3 mol dm −3 , the number of thiol molecules that are transported to the clean surface is about 3.6 × 10 −9 mol cm −2 s −1 , assuming the value of D i being 10 −5 cm 2 s −1 . This initial flux is more than enough to fully cover the surface sites in 0.1 s, forming the ( 3 × 3 ) R 30 ° structure, which gives a value of 7.6 × 10 −10 cm −2 for the number of adsorption sites on Au(1 1 1). This is in fact a simplified picture for the time-dependence of adsorption, because the incorporation of an adsorption isotherm inevitably leads to much longer time for the full coverage [46] . Nevertheless, the value estimated provides a rule of thumb for the time required for full coverage. Practically, a gold surface would be fully covered with thiols immediately after the immersion of a gold substrate unless c total is extremely small, because the immersion and the succeeding withdrawal of a substrate should cause the hydrodynamic turbulence of the bathing solution. It is then likely that adsorbed MES (AET) can easily find AET (MES) in the vicinity, either in the adjacent sites or in the solution next to the surface, to form an electrostatically stabilized ion pair on the surface. In the present study, MES and AET are dissolved as salts, NaMES and AETHCl, in the bathing solution. However, the conductance measurements (data not shown) showed a monotonous change when the mixing ratio of NaMES and AETHCl was changed while keeping c total at 1 × 10 −3 mol dm −3 . The ion pair formation of MES and AET in the ethanol solution is thus negligible. On the other hand, the lateral electrostatic interaction between adsorbed MES and AET should be enhanced on the surface where the dielectric constant is lower than in the bulk. Another possibility, the formation of an ion pair between the adsorbed MES (AET) and AET (MES) in the solution side, seems to be negligible, because there is no FTIR signal in the 2560 cm −1 region for the SH group in the coadsorption of MES and AET [30] . The formation of isolated ion pairs on the surface would not give the reductive desorption peak at −0.68 V that is ascribed to the domains of MES and AET [29] consisting of more than several tens pairs [8] . In fact, the curves a–d in Fig. 4 show a peak at potentials more positive than −0.68 V. We speculate that once the pair is formed on the surface the dipole-ion and multipole-ion interactions further facilitate the growth of MES–AET domains in a cooperative manner. MES–AET domains seem to limit the orientation of DDeT molecules on the surface by restricting the surface available to DDeT for the adsorption. A plausible explanation is to assume a mechanism that the squeezing of lying-down DDeT molecules by prompt growth of MES–AET domains results in the formation of heaps of DDeT in the sea of MES–AET and facilitated the standing-up orientation of DDeT molecules. This picture is in harmony with the fact that the size and the distribution of the DDeT-rich domains in STM images are unchanged over 8 days ( Fig. 11 ). The long-term stability of MES–AET domains over one week against DDeT in PS-mode I suggests a certain mechanism that significantly slows down the replacement of adsorbed MES–AET domains with DDeT in the solution phase. As the replacement of MES and AET with DDeT does take place when c total ⩽ 1 × 10 −5 mol dm −3 , the MES–AET domains in the PS-mode I should have a certain barrier against the attack of DDeT from the solution side. Given the hydrophobicity of DDeT molecules, we believe that the hydrophilic surface of MES–AET domains once formed prevents the approach of DDeT molecules in the close proximity. A similar slower replacement of hydrophilic domains with hydrophobic thiols forming domains stabilized by hydrogen bonding has been found in the SAM of mercaptododecanoic acid with dodecanethiol [47] . When c total ⩽ 1 × 10 −5 mol dm −3 , an adsorbed thiolate molecule will see few neighbors on the adjacent sites at short immersion time. A thiol molecule that arrives at the surface would adsorb on the surface without being influenced by neighboring thiolate molecules. This supposition is confirmed in the similar Q values for Peaks I and II at c total = 1 × 10 −6 and 1 × 10 −5 mol dm −3 at short t imrs values ( Figs. 6 a and b). Only after some time, adsorbed molecules would feel the influence of other adsorbed molecules. Isolated MES and AET molecules on the surface would readily be separated by adsorbed DDeT or even replaced with DDeT through the exchange reaction. The latter process is traced as the growth of Peak II with t imrs in Fig. 6 b. In the PS-mode II, the difference in the intrinsic adsorptivity between MES–AET and DDeT is thus reflected in the surface composition. An interesting question is why the thresholding value of c total is about 0.3 × 10 −3 mol dm −3 . We hypothesize that the density of adsorbed molecules at the very early stage of the SAM formation is crucial in determining the adsorption modes. For creating a MES–AET pair or a nucleus for a MES–AET domain, sporadically adsorbed MES and AET should find a partner, AET and MES, respectively, in the vicinity, before they are replaced with DDeT. This competitive process seems to determine the thresholding level of c total . The replacement reaction is a slow process, as can be envisaged in the disappearance of Peak I after 8 days of immersion in Fig. 4 . A simple but plausible picture is that for the cooperative formation of the MES–AET domains adsorbed MES (AET) must find AET (MES) in one of the nearest neighbor sites before encountering DDeT in one of the nearest neighbors. If we take the time for the full coverage estimated by Eq. (1) as an approximate measure of the time scale of finding the partner in the adjacent site, the time for the full coverage at c total = 1 × 10 −3 mol dm −3 would be on the order of 0.2 s. If the time scale of the replacement reaction is longer than 0.4 s, the MES–AET domains prevail. Though no data is available for the rate of the replacement of an isolated thiolate on Au(1 1 1), this time scale seems to be in harmony with the time scale of the disappearance of Peak I in Fig. 4 . Further experiments of the formation of ternary MES–AET–DDeT SAMs with changing χ DDeT soln would find a clue to estimate a more detailed picture of the thresholding. 4 Conclusions The MES–AET pair shows unusually strong surface activity in comparison with that of DDeT, only when c total is higher than 3 × 10 −4 mol dm −3 . The relative rates of two competitive processes, the formation of electrostatically stabilized MES–AET domains and the replacement of sporadically adsorbed MES and AET with DDeT, determine the threshold level of c total for the reversal of the predominant species in the ternary SAM. Once the MES–AET domains are formed, this kinetically-trapped hydrophilic domains are resistant to the replacement by DDeT in the solution phase and are stable over one week in the ethanolic solution containing DDeT on the order of × 10 −3 mol dm −3 . This type of domain formation can be made use of in designing multi-component SAMs. Acknowledgements This work was supported by a Grant-in-Aid for Scientific Research (No. 14205120) and a Grant-in-Aid for Exploratory Research (No. 15655008) from the Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science, and Technology, Japan. 1RCJDh2y.title: Structure of the Pt(111)/liquid interface: a first-principles/RHNC calculation
1RCJDh2y.abstract: Structure of the Pt(111)/dipolar liquid interface has been investigated by fully self-consistent combination of the first-principles calculation based on quantum mechanics for the metal and the reference hypernetted-chain (RHNC) theory for the liquid. The electronic density profile for the metal, density and orientational structure of liquid molecules, and electrostatic potential across the interface are discussed in detail. A dense layer of liquid molecules, which is orientationally ordered, is formed near the metal surface, but this surface-induced structure extends about only three molecular diameters from the surface. This result is in good accord with the recent experimental observations.

f9nfRO8a.title: Phase separation of ternary self-assembled monolayers into hydrophobic 1-dodecanethiol domains and electrostatically stabilized hydrophilic domains composed of 2-aminoethanethiol and 2-mercaptoethanesulfonic acid on Au(111).
f9nfRO8a.abstract: Ternary self-assembled monolayers (SAM) composed of 2-aminoethanethiol (AET), 2-mercaptoethanesulfonic acid (MES), and 1-dodecanethiol (DDeT) form two types of domains as if it were a two-component SAM: DDeT-rich hydrophobic domains and electrostatically stabilized hydrophilic domains composed of MES and AET on Au(111). MES and AET behave virtually as a single surface-active species. Two distinct reductive desorption peaks in cyclic voltammograms (CV) and binarized images of scanning tunneling microscopy clearly show nanometer scale, yet macroscopically distinguishable, phase separation over a wide range of the mixing ratio of DDeT and MES-AET in the bathing solution. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy measurements indicate that the ratio of MES to AET in the hydrophilic domains is unity and that both terminal groups are in the charged states, that is, the sulfonate group and the ammonium group. With decreasing the total concentration of the thiols, the mole fraction of DDeT in the bathing solution at which the surface coverage of MES-AET domains is equal to that of DDeT domains dramatically decreases. This suggests that the adsorption kinetics plays a crucial role in the formation of the domains structure.

vR6P7TD7.title: Artificially phase-separated binary self-assembled monolayers composed of 11-amino-1-undecanethiolate and 10-carboxy-1-decanethiolate on Au(111): A comparative study of two preparing methods
vR6P7TD7.abstract: Two methods have been compared for preparing artificially phase-separated two-component SAMs on Au(1 1 1) composed of 11-amino-1-undecanethiolates (AUTe) and 10-carboxyl-1-decanethiolates (CDTe), which would form, thermodynamically, a homogeneously mixed binary SAMs. The first method starts with the formation of a phase-separated binary SAM of AUTe and 2-hydroxy-1-ethanethiolate (HETe) as a template of the artificially phase-separated SAM, followed by the selective desorption of HETe domains and succeeding filling of the vacancy with CDTe. The second method utilizes fluoren-9-ylmethyl N -(11-mercaptoundecyl) carbamate (FMUCe) instead of 11-amino-1-undecanethiol in preparing the template. After the filling with CDTe, the 9-fluorenylmethyloxycarbonyl (Fmoc) group is removed to obtain AUTe domains. Both methods yield artificially phase-separated binary SAMs having AUTe domains of tens nanometer across. The molecularly flat SAM surface with nanometer-scale domains of different acid-base and electrostatic properties are thus created. For preparing binary SAMs with a higher degree of phase separation, the second method is a better choice; a more clear-cut phase separation is achieved. Keywords Self-assembled monolayer SAM Binary self-assembled monolayer Phase separation Artificial phase separation 11-amino-1-undecanethiol 10-carboxyl-1-decanethiol Fmoc Fluoren-9-ylmethyl N -(11-mercaptoundecyl)carbamate

TkKf2Kn5.title: Determination of the potential of zero charge of Au(111) electrodes modified with thiol self-assembled monolayers using a potential-controlled sessile drop method
TkKf2Kn5.abstract: The potential of zero charge (pzc) of the thiol-modified Au(1 1 1) electrode has been determined for self-assembled monolayers (SAMs) of octadecanethiolate (ODT), undecanethiolate (UDT), propanethiolate (PT), and 1H,1H,2H,2H-perfluorodecanethiolate (PFDT) by measuring the contact angle of a drop of an aqueous 0.1 mol dm −3 NaClO 4 solution on the SAM-covered electrode as a function of the electrode potential. The values of the pzc for ODT, UDT, PT, and PFDT SAMs were −0.52, −0.49. −0.3, and 1.04 V (vs. Ag|AgCl|satd. KCl), respectively. The variation of the values is ascribed to the change in the surface potential on the solution side of the electrode|solution interface due to the difference in the dipole moments of alkanethiolates on Au(1 1 1), which is supported by the ab initio calculation of these thiolates adsorbed on a four-atom cluster of Au atoms. Keywords Potential of zero charge Pzc Self assembled monolayers SAM Contact angle Electro-capillary curve 1 Introduction There have been several attempts to determine the potential of zero charge (pzc) for the thiol-modified electrode surface [1–5] , as the pzc is one of the fundamental parameters that determine the properties of the electrical double-layer, which can in turn affect the electrode reaction on the surface and other surface properties, such as wetting. Sondag-Huethorst and Fokkink first introduced the Wilhelmy method for determining the pzc of thiol-covered polycrystalline electrodes and estimated the pzc of the self-assembled monolayer (SAM) of octadecanethiolate (ODT) in contact with 0.01 mol dm −3 K 2 SO 4 to be located at −0.45 V (vs. SCE) [1] , which is about 0.8 V more negative to the pzc of bare gold in contact with 0.1 mol dm −3 NaClO 4 , 0.33 V (vs. SCE) [6] . The chain length of the alkanethiolate did not significantly affect the location of the pzc; the SAMs of dodecanethiolate and behenoylthiolate on gold show similar pzc values [3] , which seems to be at variance with the surface potential measurements for a series of alkanethiol SAMs [7] . On the other hand, the substitution of the ω-terminal to another polar group resulted in a marked shift of the pzc [4] in the positive direction. This shift is consistent with the double layer capacitance measurements of ω-hydroxyltetradecanethiolate SAM on gold in contact with submillimolar aqueous sodium trifluoroacetate at 0 °C [2] . As the packing of alkanethiolate molecules on polycrystalline gold is likely to be less ordered [8] , the contact angle and other electrocapillary properties of SAMs formed on a single crystal surface or a metal surface of similar quality are desirable in further studies of the double layer properties of SAM-covered electrodes. crystal surface, the sessile drop method is preferable to the Wilhelmy method. For this purpose, the contact angle of a sessile drop is preferable to the Wilhelmy plate method, in that a small droplet of an aqueous or other solution can be placed on a single crystal surface or its equivalent. The control of the potential drop across the droplet solution and the electrode surface is feasible through electrodes inserted into the droplet. In fact, the potential-dependent wetting has been achieved in the case of a larger drop of 10 s of mm diameter by controlling the potential drop across the interface between the drop and the SAM on a polycrystalline gold substrate by inserting Ag and Pt wires [9,10] . In this paper, we report the contact angle measurements of an aqueous solution on Au(1 1 1)-facet-prevalent electrodes covered with alkanethiolate SAMs using a sessile drop under potential-controlled conditions, which is achieved by inserting a reference electrode and a counter electrode in an aqueous droplet of less than 1 μl. 2 Experimental 1-octadecanethiol (ODT; Aldrich), 1-undecanethiol (UDT; Tokyo Kasei, Japan), 1-propanethiol (PT; Aldrich), and 1H,1H,2H,2H-perfluorodecanethiol (PFDT; ABCR, Germany) were used without further purification. Other reagents were of reagent grade. Gold (99.99%) was vapor-deposited on freshly cleaved mica sheets at a reduced pressure, <1.3×10 −3 Pa. The temperature of the mica sheet was maintained at 580 °C during the vapor deposition. The Au-deposited mica sheets were subsequently annealed at 550 °C for 8 h and then quenched in water to obtain Au(1 1 1), facet-prevailing gold substrates, which in 0.01 mol dm −3 HClO 4 gave cyclic voltammograms whose shape well agreed with that reported in the literature [11] . STM imaging also confirmed the prevalence of Au(1 1 1) terraces on the sheets thus prepared. The roughness factor of the Au surface was estimated to be 1.05 from the underpotential deposition of Pb 2+ [12] . Alkanethiol SAMs were prepared by immersing Au-coated mica substrates for at least 24 h in an ethanol solution containing an alkanethiol at 1 mmol dm −3 . The substrate was then washed first with ethanol and then water, and dried under a stream of dry argon gas. Cyclic voltammograms of the reductive desorption of alkanethiol SAMs were recorded in 0.5 mol dm −3 KOH using a Ag|AgCl|saturated KCl electrode (SSSE) as the reference electrode and a platinum wire as the counter electrode. The solution was deaerated with argon bubbling for at least 10 min. Fig. 1 illustrates the arrangement of the experimental setup for contact angle measurements. A SAM-coated gold substrate was placed on a XYZ stage. The level of the stage was adjusted with a spirit level. A drop of 0.8 μl aqueous 0.1 mol dm −3 NaClO 4 solution was put on the center of the gold electrode. Such a small volume of the droplet was used, so that the shape of the drop was approximated as spherical in the contact angle analysis. The shape of the drop was captured with a CCD video camera (640 × 480 pixels, CS3300, Tokyo Electronics, Japan) with lighting from the backside of the drop using a tungsten lamp. A glass capillary having an orifice of about 1 μm, filled with saturated aqueous KCl solution and a Ag|AgCl wire as a reference electrode, was inserted into a drop on the hidden side from the video camera, so that the shape of the drop in the video image was not distorted. A platinum wire of 1 μm diameter was inserted in the drop as a counter electrode in a similar manner. The XYZ stage, the two electrodes that were connected to a head box housing an operational amplifier for a potentiostat circuit (HECS-972 head box, Fusou, Japan), and the video camera, were housed in a shield box. Fig. 2(a) and (b) show the thresholded images of the sessile drops before and after the insertion of the electrodes into the drop, respectively. Fig. 2(c) shows that these two images are completely superimposable, assuring that by choosing the location of the insertion properly, the effect of the two electrodes on the shape captured as a video image of the drop can be minimized. Video images from the video camera were converted to digital data using a media converter (DVMC-MS1, Sony, Japan) and stored in a personal computer. From the circumference of the video image of a drop, we evaluated the contact angle, assuming that the shape of the drop is spherical, using the relation: tan θ 2 = 2h d , where θ is the contact angle, h is the height of the apex of the drop from the substrate surface, and d is the diameter of the circle of the drop contacting the substrate. We did not control the humidity inside the shielding box when recording the contact angle at a scan rate of 20 mV s −1 over 400 mV, that is, for 20 s. In the case of 50% relative humidity, the contact angle gradually decreased with time at the rate of ≈0.8 ° min −1 . For measurements at lower scan rates, control of the humidity seems to be desirable. The reversal of the potential usually gave higher values of the contact angle at positive potentials due to the hysteresis. A glass capillary used for the reference electrode was prepared by drawing a glass tube of 1 mm outer and 0.6 mm inner diameters with a central core of a glass fiber (GDC-1, Narishige, Japan) using a pipette puller (PC-10, Narishige), so that the tip orifice became ≈1 μm outer diameter. The capillary was then filled with a saturated KCl solution and a Ag|AgCl electrode was sealed into the capillary with epoxy resin. All experiments were made at ambient temperature, 25±2 °C. 3 Results and discussion First, we examined the controllability of the potential between the aqueous 0.1 mol dm −3 NaClO 4 solution in the drop and the UDT-modified electrode by measuring the contact angle as a function of the applied voltage, E . The results are shown in Fig. 3 . The contact angle of about 102° was constant from −0.8 to −1.1 V and then decreased sharply to 70° when E was changed from −1.1 to −1.3 V. This decrease reflects the reductive desorption of adsorbed UDT [13,14] and clearly demonstrates that the potential across the microdroplet and the SAM-modified gold electrode is controlled with the reference micropipette capillary and the counter electrode. Voltammograms of the reductive desorption of UDT SAM recorded separately also gave a peak at this potential (data not shown, see also [15] ). Fig. 4(a)–(d) show the results of the contact angle measurements for ODT, UDT, PT, and PFDT SAMs in contact with 0.1 mol dm −3 NaClO 4 . The potential was scanned from 0.85 to −0.9 V, where the reductive desorption was absent, at a scan rate of 20 mV s −1 . Vertical bars in Fig. 4(a)–(d) show the standard deviation for at least quintuplet measurements. For alkanethiol SAMs, the scanning of the potential resulted in higher contact angles at negative potentials, exhibiting a maximum. By fitting experimental data to a fourth-order polynomial (solid lines in Fig. 4(a)–(d) ), we obtained the potential, E max , for each curve where the contact angle had a maximum ( Table 1 ). In general, the contact angle ( θ ) is related to the interfacial tensions of three boundaries through Young’s equation [16] , γ sg =γ sl +γ lg cos θ, where γ sg , γ sl , and γ lg are the interfacial tension between the solid|gas, solid|liquid, and liquid|gas interfaces, respectively. In the present experiment, it is reasonable to assume that γ sg and γ lg remain unchanged during the scan of the voltage. Therefore the change in θ with E is a measure of the change in γ sl with E , (1) ∂ γ sl ∂ E=γ lg sin θ ∂ θ ∂ E . On the other hand, for solid electrodes, the Gibbs–Duhem equation at constant temperature is given by [17,18] : (2) − d γ=σ M d E+∑ i Γ i d μ i +(γδ pq −g pq ) d ϵ pq , where γ ≡ γ sl , σ M is the excess surface charge density in the metal electrode, Γ i and μ i are the relative surface excess and the chemical potential of the component i , δ pq is Kronecker delta, g pq is the stress, ϵ pq is the strain, and the subscript pq means that the sum of the terms is taken when an index appears twice. Then, the generalized Lippmann equation has the form [17] : (3) − ∂ γ ∂ E T,μ i =σ M +(γδ pq −g pq ) ∂ ϵ pq ∂ E T,μ i . According to the analysis of the gold electrode, the last term is much smaller than the first term and, hence, the surface charge density can be measured electrochemically [17,19,20] . The potential at the maximum contact angle vs. E plot should then correspond to the pzc, that is, E max = E pzc . The value of E pzc for ODT, −0.52 V (vs. SSSE) is close to −0.42 V (vs. SCE), that is, −0.46 V (vs. SSSE) of ODT SAM on polycrystalline gold [3] and −0.40 V (vs. SCE) for dodecanethiolate SAM on polycrystalline gold probed by the Stark effect [5] . With decreasing chain length, E pzc shifted in the positive direction: −0.49 V for UDT and −0.30 V for PT. Such a shift of E pzc with the alkyl chain length was not observed for alkanethiol SAMs on polycrystalline gold for n =11, 17, and 21 [3] , where n is the number of methylene moieties. The curvature of the plots in Fig. 4(a)–(c) becomes greater with decreasing n . This agrees with the results of contact angle measurements using the Wilhelmy method with polycrystalline gold [3] and reflects the increase in the capacitance of the SAMs with decreasing n [3] . This also agrees with the finding from impedance measurements that the decanethiol SAM on Au(1 1 1) in contact with the aqueous NaClO 4 at the pzc of bare Au(1 1 1) can be represented as a capacitor in series with the solution resistance [21] . For alkanethiol SAMs, the contact angle of water increases with increasing chain length [22] . This trend is the same as the results in Table 1 . In the present case, however, the contact angle values at E pzc were 103.3, 99.8, and 84.0° for ODT, UDT, and PT, respectively. These values are lower than the advancing contact angle of the SAMs on polycrystalline gold, 118° for sufficiently long alkanethiolates [23,24] , and are comparable with receding contact angles of about 100° [23,24] . As the scanning from positive to negative potential causes the increase in the contact angle, the data shown in Fig. 4(a)–(c) are to be understood as receding angles that are about 10° lower than the corresponding advancing angles for alkanethiolate SAMs and water [23,25] . The decrease in the contact angle with shortening chain length of the alkanethiolates in SAMs is usually ascribed to the looser packing of the adsorbed molecules [22,26] . On the other hand, however, the STM imaging of PT and HDT from STM on Au(1 1 1) shows that shorter alkanethiolates also fully cover the Au(1 1 1) surface [27,28] ; the surface density of the methyl-terminal group does not vary with n . A recent sum frequency generation (SFG) study suggested that the all- trans conformation is retained even for SAMs with a shorter alkyl chain length such as PT, and SAMs with shorter alkyl chain lengths are a few degrees more tilted from the surface normal in comparison with SAMs of longer alkyl chain alkanethiolates [29] . It is therefore likely that the surface density of alkanethiolates on Au(1 1 1) remains unchanged with n and there is no significant disorder of the alkyl chain part of the SAMs with smaller n . Smaller contact angles for PT SAM would rather reflect the fact that the value of the contact angle is determined not only by the nature of the ω terminal group, but also by the internal energy and entropy of the entire system. In the case of the PDFT SAMs, the contact angle did not show a marked dependence on the applied potential, but exhibited a curve with a slightly convex curvature. The maximum is located at 1.04 V, which is 1.5 V more positive than those for alkanethiolate SAMs and is also 0.7 V more positive than the pzc of bare Au(1 1 1) in contact with 0.1 mol dm −3 NaClO 4 [6] . Sondag-Huethorst and Fokkink [4] showed that the replacement of the ω methyl terminal group by nitrile or chloride causes a positive shift of the maximum by ≈0.7 V. The shift observed in the present results of PDFT SAMs is much greater than those reported previously. The contact angle of 0.1 mol dm −3 NaClO 4 on PDFT SAM at E max was 114.7°, which is slightly lower than the contact angles of water with SAMs of CF 3 (CH 2 ) n SH ( n =9–15) [24] , 118°, and 117° for CF 3 (Cf 2 ) 10 (CH 2 ) 2 SH [25] . The shift in the pzc with adsorption from the solution side is related to the change in the surface potential before and after the adsorption [30,31] : (4) E pzc =Φ+δχ M + δ χ S + const , where Φ is the work function of the metal, δ χ M (δ χ S ) is the change in the surface potential on the metal side (solution side) upon contacting the solution (metal) and const includes the quantities related to the reference electrode. As the difference in HDT, UDT, PT, and PFDT resides only in the alkyl part of the molecules and the surface coverage of all thiols is the same for all thiolates studied, δ χ M presumably remains the same for all thiols studied. Then the change in E pzc is ascribed to the change in δ χ S , which is mainly determined by the dipole moment of the adsorbed molecules. The variation of E pzc in Table 1 should therefore be related to the difference in the dipole moment of adsorbed alkanethiolates. Evans and Ulman measured the surface potential for a series of alkanethiolate SAMs using the Kelvin probe method and found that the surface potential, χ , increases linearly with n (6⩽ n ⩽21) and the variation of χ with n was 9.3 mV [7] . A tendency to saturation of the χ values was not observed up to n =21 [7] . Though the present E pzc data for three alkanethiolate SAMs are not sufficient to obtain reliable estimates, the negative shift in E pzc by about 15 mV per n is in harmony with their surface potential measurements. The fact that the difference in E pzc between UDT to ODT is smaller than that between PT and UDT and the finding by Sondag-Huethorst and Fokkink about the insensitiveness of their E max values on n , n =11, 17, 21, may reflect the tendency in the saturation of the surface potential for alkanethiolate SAMs with larger n values. To elucidate this point further, we made ab initio calculations of the dipole moment, μ D , of alkanethiolates adsorbed on the gold atom cluster using the Gaussian 98 code [32] with the LanL2DZ basis set, i.e., the Dunning/Huzinaga full double zeta (DZ) basis set [33] for hydrogen, carbon and fluorine and the Los Alamos effective core potential plus DZ basis for sulfur and gold [34,35] . In the density functional calculation Becke’s three parameter hybrid functional [36] using the Lee and Parr correlation [37] was used. The structures of the thiol-gold clusters were fully relaxed except that the gold positions were fixed and the sulfur atom was located at the hollow site. The relaxed structures and the calculated dipole moments for UDT, PT, and PFDT are shown in Fig. 5 . In the case of alkanethiolates on gold, the alkyl chain takes an all- trans configuration even for PT, which agrees with the recent SFG study of alkanethiolate SAMs on Au(1 1 1) [29] . In contrast, the perfluoroalkyl chain of PFDT exhibits the helical conformation, which is known for perfluorinated hydrocarbons [38–40] . The charge on the sulfur atom is negative in all cases calculated and does not depend very much on the type of the alkyl group: −0.34, −0.36, −0.36, and −0.39 for ODT, UDT, PT, and PFDT, respectively. The gold cluster is slightly positively charged in all cases: 0.09, 0.08, and 0.11 for ODT, UDT, PT, and PFDT. As the conformation of the alkyl chain part of ODT did not converge, we calculated the dipole moment of the alkanethiolate-gold cluster only for UDT, PT, and PFDT to be 2.22, 1.70, and 3.84 D ( D =3.33564×10 −30 C m), respectively ( Fig. 5 ); the dipoles for the UDT and PT are directing their negative end toward the electrode surface, whereas the PFDT directs its positive end toward the electrode surface, owing to the electronegative characters of the fluorine atoms, as has been described by Evans and Ulman in interpreting the surface potential measurements of perfluorinated alkanethiolate SAMs [7] . The nature of the alkyl chain part is thus crucial in determining the dipole moment of the adsorbed alkanethiolates on gold. The relationship between the value of E pzc and the surface normal component of the calculated dipole moment, μ ⊥ , was found to be linear for UDT, PT, and PFDT. The tilt angle of an isolated alkanethiolate molecule adsorbed on the gold cluster was about 10° from the surface normal: 10°, 14°, and 12° for UDT, PT, and PFDT, respectively, where the tilt angle is defined as the angle that the line connecting S–C 2 –C 4 in the all trans configuration makes with respect to the surface normal. It is known that the tilt angle of the alkyl chain is about 30° for long chain alkanethiolates in the SAM on Au(1 1 1) and becomes greater with decreasing n [29] . For precise evaluation of the contribution of these adsorbed thiolates to the surface potential, a more accurate evaluation of the tilt angle, which is determined not only by the nature of the Au–S–C bonding but the intermolecular interactions of adsorbed thiolates and the site of the adsorption, seems to be required [41] . The size of the gold cluster also probably affects the value of the dipole moment. Nevertheless, the difference in the magnitude and the direction of the dipole moment of the thiolate-Au cluster complex explains, at least qualitatively, the shift of E pzc with the alkyl chain length and also the large positive shift in E pzc for the PFDT SAM. 4 Conclusions A new method of measuring the contact angle under the precise control of the potential drop across the droplet|Au(1 1 1) interface has been presented. The combination of a small drop of microliter size and a reference electrode of a glass capillary type enables reproducible contact angle vs. potential curves to be obtained. The negative shift in E pzc of alkanethiolate SAMs on Au(1 1 1) with increasing chain length, and also the large positive shift in E pzc for the perfluorinated alkane SAM, are attributable to the difference in the surface dipole moments of adsorbed thiolate molecules. The proposed method is promising to elucidate further the double layer structure on SAM surfaces. MiVrmoWS.title: Effect of the charged state of gold substrates on the surface composition of two-component alkanethiol self-assembled monolayers
MiVrmoWS.abstract: The surface composition of the binary self-assembled monolayer (SAM) of 1-tetradecanethiol and 3-mercapto-1-propanol on gold varies with the charged state of the gold substrate because of the difference in the reductive desorption potentials of the two thiol species. This is a direct corollary of the finding by Paik et al. [S. Eu, W.K. Paik, Chem. Lett. 16 (1998) 405–406.] that the adsorption of thiols to a metal surface from the solution phase leads to the accumulation of negative charges on the surface. By controlling the potential of the gold substrate during the formation of a binary SAM, it is possible to change the surface composition. The saturation of the bathing ethanol solution with oxygen and the grounding of the substrate during the formation of the SAM have basically the same effect on the surface composition, as both mitigate the charge-up problem.

wc3eVNUN.title: Significant elevation of serum human hepatocyte growth factor levels in patients with acute pancreatitis.
wc3eVNUN.abstract: Serum levels of human hepatocyte growth factor (HGF) were determined in 38 patients with acute pancreatitis by an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay. The mean value of serum HGF levels on admission in the 38 patients was 1.69 +/- 0.40 (SEM) ng/ml. In 35 patients, serum HGF levels were found to be positive (> 0.39 ng/ml), with an incidence of 92.1%. In 17 patients, they were > 1.0 ng/ml, which was the cutoff value for fulminant hepatic failure. Serum HGF levels in the patients with severe acute pancreatitis (2.30 +/- 0.61 ng/ml; mean +/- SEM) were significantly higher than those in the patients with mild and moderate acute pancreatitis (0.63 +/- 0.06 ng/ml). Sixteen of seventeen patients whose serum HGF levels were > 1.0 ng/ml were evaluated as severe acute pancreatitis. Serum HGF levels were significantly elevated in the patients with higher Ranson scores, higher APACHE II scores, or higher computed tomography grades. Serum HGF levels in the patients with organ dysfunction (liver, kidney, or lung) were significantly higher than those in the patients without organ dysfunction. Moreover, serum HGF levels on admission in the nonsurvivors (3.17 +/- 1.30 ng/ml) were significantly higher than those in the survivors (1.22 +/- 0.33 ng/ml). The mortality rate of the patients showing serum HGF levels > 2.0 ng/ml on admission was 50%. In the patients with a lethal outcome, the mean serum HGF level remained constantly > 2.50 ng/ml during hospitalization. The serum HGF level reflected the clinical course of the disease rapidly and distinctly. Serum HGF levels increased with complications such as organ failure, infected pancreatic necrosis, and sepsis and decreased with successful intensive and surgical treatments. These results suggest that serum human HGF levels may reflect the severity, organ dysfunction, and prognosis in acute pancreatitis.

OJfzFMPk.title: Papillary hyperplasia of the pancreas.
OJfzFMPk.abstract: We report the first case of surgically resected pure papillary hyperplasia of the pancreas. Interestingly, it was not associated with chronic pancreatitis or pancreatic cancer. Histologic and immunohistochemical features are described, with a review of the literature on papillary hyperplasia of the pancreas.

odqlbdbO.title: Nocturnal 5-fluorouracil infusion to patients with breast cancer prior to surgery: appearance of 5-fluorouracil-induced AgNORs aggregation (FAA).
odqlbdbO.abstract: Between 1994 and 1995, 1 day nocturnal infusion of 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) was performed prior to surgery in 13 primary breast cancer patients; 300 mg/m2 of 5-FU was infused constantly from 2100 h to 0700 h via peripheral vein with a volumetric pump. 5-FU concentration in tissues was measured within surgical specimens by HPLC. The concentrations of 5-FU in tumor tissues ranged from 6 to 49 ng/g (average +/- SEM 25.0 +/- 4.1 ng/g), while in normal breast tissues and adipose tissues 5-FU was below the detection limit (<3 ng/g). The 5-FU concentration was lower in estrogen-receptor-positive tumors (14.4 +/- 4.5 ng/g) than in estrogen-receptor-negative tumors (31.8 +/- 5.0 ng/g). Typical FAA was observed in the tumor tissues of three patients. In these three cases, AgNORs were aggregated to one large spheroidal figure in more than 39% of tumor cells. Appearance of FAA could not be predicted by other clinical features. Nocturnal 5-FU infusion caused FAA changes in certain types of primary breast cancer.

THZOMpCw.title: Surgical significance of telomerase activity in noncancerous liver tissue from patients with hepatocellular carcinoma.
THZOMpCw.abstract: Telomerase activity has been detected in tissue from noncancerous liver of patients with chronic liver disease, but its functional significance remains to be elucidated. We therefore evaluated the telomerase activity in surgically obtained noncancerous liver tissue from 20 hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) patients. Two samples of noncancerous liver tissue were obtained from each patient: one from the parenchyma adjacent to the HCC nodules of the resected specimen; the other from the parenchyma distant from the HCC nodules of the remnant liver. Telomerase activity was assayed by a non-radioisotope quantitative system based on "TRAP-eze." Five samples from the noncancerous liver tissue adjacent to the HCC nodules (25.0%) were telomerase-positive; all such cases showed high-grade malignant potential, such as intrahepatic metastasis and/or portal vascular invasion and infiltration of the fibrous capsule in the corresponding HCC nodules, and telomerase positivity showed neither a relationship with the histological activity index scores nor a correlation with liver function. Interestingly, no telomerase activity was detected in any of the 20 samples obtained from the parenchyma of the remnant liver. These results indicate that telomerase in noncancerous liver tissue is associated not with the hepatic condition accompanying HCC, but with the biological characteristics of the tumor itself, and may derive from infiltrating cancer cells. Determination of telomerase status may aid in designing more effective surgical procedures.
THZOMpCw.venue: Japanese journal of cancer research : Gann

iqVP6REv.title: Effect of a selective inhibitor of secretory phospholipase A2, S-5920/LY315920Na, on experimental acute pancreatitis in rats.
iqVP6REv.abstract: We investigated the efficacy of a potent inhibitor of secretory phospholipase A2 (sPLA2), S-5920/LY315920Na, in an experimental model of acute pancreatitis in rats. Combined intraductal injection of sodium taurocholate (5 mg/rat) and porcine pancreatic sPLA2-IB (300 microg/rat) caused severe hemorrhagic necrotizing pancreatitis resulting in high mortality, along with rapid increases of catalytic PLA2 and lipase activities in plasma and ascites and with gradual increases of plasma amylase and aspartate aminotransferase levels over 9 h after the pancreatitis. Prophylactic intravenous treatment with S-5920/LY315920Na significantly reduced mortality at 7 days, and strongly abrogated PLA2 activities in both plasma and ascites along with significant reduction of lipase activity, amylase, aspartate aminotransferase, and hemorrhage at 6 h. It also significantly reduced histological damage such as edema and parenchymal and fat necroses of the pancreatic tissue. This sPLA2 inhibitor could become an effective agent for the treatment of severe acute pancreatitis.

xMcMifaE.title: Complete agenesis of the dorsal pancreas.
xMcMifaE.abstract: Pancreatic anomalies are occasionally reported, but complete agenesis of the dorsal pancreas is extremely rare. We report a 47-year-old woman with complete agenesis of the dorsal pancreas. This patient initially presented with jaundice. Computed tomography did not reveal the pancreatic corpus or tail. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography and magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography did not visualize the dorsal pancreatic duct. Choledochojejunostomy was performed because she had obstructive jaundice. At laparotomy, there was an enlarged pancreatic head, but no distal pancreas was seen. Histological examination of the pancreatic biopsy specimen showed scattered islets of Langerhans in diffuse fibrosis, with destruction of the glandular parenchyma. This case was diagnosed as complete agenesis of the dorsal pancreas.

252EeUGg.title: Detection of point mutations in K-ras gene at codon 12 in bile from percutaneous transhepatic choledochal drainage tubes for diagnosis of biliary strictures.
252EeUGg.abstract:
Summary  Detection of K-ras mutations at codon 12 constitutes one modality for diagnosis of pancreatic tumors. We attempted to detect K-ras mutations in DNA from bile collected through percutaneous transhepatic choledochal drainage (PTCD) tubes as a diagnostic
 approach to biliary strictures. Since bile salts induce cell damage, we first investigated the degeneration of cells according
 to bile exposure time using cell lines. High-mol-wt DNA could be extracted from cells exposed to bile for 6 h, but not from
 those exposed for 12 h. However, DNA exposed to bile for up 12 h could be amplified by the polymerase chain reaction (PCR)
 method. Therefore, K-ras mutations in fresh bile specimens collected from 15 patients through PTCD tubes were examined using PCR with restriction
 enzyme digestion. K-ras mutations were found in five out of five (100%) pancreatic cancers, all of which were negative according to cytodiagnosis
 of the same bile. On the other hand, K-ras mutations were not detected in bile from biliary tract cancers or metastatic neoplasms, except for one bile duct carcinoma
 and one metastatic case. Thus, although K-ras mutation alone is not an absolute marker for cancer, detection of K-ras mutations in fresh bile from PTCD tubes is a useful adjunct for diagnosis of pancreatic carcinomas in cases of biliary tract
 strictures.

3RAaUBHn.title: The significance of CD44 in human pancreatic cancer: II. The role of CD44 in human pancreatic adenocarcinoma invasion.
3RAaUBHn.abstract: In our previous report (1), we showed the high expression of CD44 in human pancreatic adenocarcinomas cells. Pancreatic cancer aggressively invades surrounding tissues by penetrating basement membrane barriers. To examine the relation between the biological characteristics of human pancreatic adenocarcinoma cells and CD44 expression, we studied the function of CD44 in cell proliferation and cell invasion using a Matrigel basement membrane. The proliferation of human pancreatic adenocarcinoma cells was not affected by anti-CD44 antibody. On the contrary, invasion of the cells was suppressed by anti-CD44 antibody. This result suggests that the CD44 molecule plays an important role in pancreatic cancer cell invasion of the basement membrane.

teIzW6W2.title: Impaired response of gastric vessels to prostaglandin E<Subscript>2</Subscript> in rats with persistent obstructive jaundice
teIzW6W2.abstract:
We investigated the response of gastric vessels to prostaglandin (PG) E2 after intra-duodenal release of bile in rats with obstructive jaundice. The animals were divided into four groups according
 to duration of bile duct obstruction (BDO): control and 1 week (W), 2W, and 3W groups. Prolonged BDO decreased gastric mucosal
 blood flow (BF) significantly. The BF recovered after the release of BDO in the 1W and 2W groups, but not in the 3W group.
 BDO decreased PGE2 content in gastric mucosa in the 1W, 2W, and 3W groups. PGE2 decreased vascular perfusion pressure of the isolated stomach in the control and 2W groups, but not in the 3W group. The
 response of gastric vessels to PGE2 was poor in the 3W group compared with the control and 2W groups. Decreased PGE2 in the gastric mucosa and decreased response of gastric vessels to PGE2 may affect gastric blood flow in obstructive jaundice.

GeGa7ULN.title: Experimental studies on fluosol DA administration in acute pancreatitis.
GeGa7ULN.abstract: Therapeutic use of the perfluorochemical emulsion, Fluosol DA, in acute pancreatitis was experimentally discussed in view of maintaining the local blood flow and oxygen supply in the pancreas to avoid further aggravation of pancreatitis. Acute pancreatitis was induced by deoxycholate injection into the pancreatic duct in adult mongrel dogs. Fluosol DA or 6% hydroxyethylstarch (HES) solution as control was transfused at 20 ml/kg/hour for the first 3 hours. Fluosol DA and HES solution improved the depressed cardiac output and pancreatic blood flow to normal levels. Compared with HES solution, Fluosol DA administration revealed a prominent increase in oxygen tension in the pancreatic tissue, which had decreased severely from onset of pancreatitis. Fluosol DA administration brought about better preservation of pancreatic mitochondrial functions. Despite no significant differences in blood levels of other pancreatic enzymes between Fluosol DA and HES solution, the sharp decrease in plasma postheparin phospholipase A2 suggested the protection of involved systemic organs including pancreas. Thus, maintaining pancreatic blood flow and increasing the oxygen transport by Fluosol DA administration seemed to play a positive role in inhibiting the progress of pancreatitis, though improvement of survival rate in acute pancreatitis was incomplete by Fluosol DA administration alone.
GeGa7ULN.venue: Biomaterials, artificial cells, and artificial organs

xcAK0UvQ.title: An immunohistochemical study of glucagonoma conducted on the metastatic lymph nodes from a patient with recurrent metastatic glucagonoma: report of a case.
xcAK0UvQ.abstract: In this report, we briefly present the case of a 67-year-old woman who developed recurrent glucagonoma with lymph node metastasis. An immunohistochemical study of the metastatic tumor revealed immunoreactivity of glucagon and protein kinase C (PKC)-alpha, -beta, and -gamma in the tumor cells, two types of which were seen by electron microscopy. One type had abundant secretory granules and mitochondria, while the other had few granules and mitochondria. Some granules were similar to typical A cell granules and others were atypical. An immunoelectron microscopic demonstration revealed PKC-alpha, -beta, and -gamma immunostaining in the cytoplasm of all the tumor cells, while some secretory granules had PKC immunostaining, and others had no immunostaining. Thus, it appears that metastatic glucagonoma and its associated granules are composed of two types of mature and immature cells or granules. As immunoreactivity of PKC-alpha and -gamma was found in the tumor cells, but not in the normal A cells of the islets of Langerhans, the PKC subspecies alpha and gamma, which are not present in normal pancreatic A cells, may exist in human glucagonoma cells.

ESHUEwO6.title: Microsatellite instability in Japanese hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer does not induce mutation of a simple repeat sequence of the bax gene.
ESHUEwO6.abstract: The identification of frameshift mutations in the coding region of the bax gene in Western cases of hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer provided evidence that the disease could be caused by the disruption of a tumor suppressor gene associated with microsatellite instability. In order to determine whether this observation could be extended to Japanese colorectal cancers, we analyzed the simple repeat sequence of (G)8 in the bax gene of tumor genomes from 15 cases of Japanese hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer that showed microsatellite instability in at least one of four examined microsatellite loci. None of 15 tumor DNA samples had a frameshift mutation in this region of the bax gene. Our results suggest that direct disruption of the bax gene is not a major factor responsible for carcinogenesis in Japanese hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancers even though microsatellite instability is present.

u5nwHWSx.title: Clinical significance of urokinase-type plasminogen activator activity in hepatocellular carcinoma.
u5nwHWSx.abstract: The plasminogen activation system plays a crucial role in the process of cancer invasion and metastasis. To evaluate the most effective factor in the invasion, metastasis and prognosis of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), we examined urokinase-type plasminogen activator (uPA), plasminogen activator inhibitor (PAI)-1, PAI-2 and uPA activity by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays (ELISA) in HCC tissues obtained from 46 patients. The results were compared with the patients' clinicopathological features and prognoses.Of the clinicopathological features, only histological portal involvement or intrahepatic metastasis, or both (INV), was significantly correlated to the disease-free survival rates (DFS; P < 0.05). The levels of uPA, PAI-1 and PAI-2 antigens were significantly associated with INV and histological grade. The DFS was not different, however, between cases with uPA, PAI-1 and PAI-2 values above and below the median. The high levels of uPA activity were closely related to INV (P < 0.001), and the activity gradually raised histological grades (P < 0.0001). The DFS was significantly different between patients with uPA activity below and above the median (0.70 ng/mL; P = 0.0092); it was also significantly different between such patients without INV (P < 0.05).Urokinase-type plasminogen activator activity may be the most sensitive factor affecting HCC invasion in the plasminogen activation system and a strong predictor for the recurrence of HCC. We suggest that cases with uPA activity of more than 0.70 ng/mL should be carefully followed up for possible HCC recurrence.

XtzYlG6O.title: Hepatocyte growth factor in assessment of acute pancreatitis: comparison with C-reactive protein and interleukin-6.
XtzYlG6O.abstract: Serum levels of hepatocyte growth factor (HGF), C-reactive protein (CRP), and interleukin-6 (IL-6) were determined at the time of admission in 38 patients with acute pancreatitis. The clinical utility of HGF for the detection of severe pancreatitis and for predicting prognosis, bacterial infection (infected pancreatic necrosis or sepsis), and organ dysfunction (liver, kidney, and lung) during the clinical course of acute pancreatitis was compared with the clinical utility of CRP and IL-6 by analysis of receiver operator characteristic (ROC) curves. The optimum cutoff levels of HGF for severity, prognosis, infection, hepatic dysfunction, renal dysfunction, and respiratory dysfunction were 0.9, 1.1, 1.0, 1.1, 1.1, and 1.0 ng/ml, respectively. HGF was as useful as CRP and more useful than IL-6 for detection of severe pancreatitis and for predicting hepatic dysfunction. Moreover, HGF was more useful than CRP or IL-6 for predicting prognosis, renal dysfunction, and respiratory dysfunction. However, for predicting infection, CRP was more useful than HGF. These results suggest that serum HGF levels on admission may be a useful new clinical parameter for determining the prognosis of acute pancreatitis and that HGF may be closely related to the organ dysfunction of acute pancreatitis.

kTdRCsI1.title: Hepatocyte growth factor increases in injured organs and functions as an organotrophic factor in rats with experimental acute pancreatitis.
kTdRCsI1.abstract: We previously reported that serum hepatocyte growth factor (HGF) levels are elevated in patients with acute pancreatitis and that pancreatitis-associated ascitic fluid (PAAF) contains cytotoxic factor(s) inducing apoptosis on Madin-Darby canine kidney (MDCK) cells. In this study, plasma HGF levels and HGF tissue distribution were investigated in rats with experimental acute pancreatitis, and the effects of HGF on the cytotoxic activity and apoptosis-inducing activity of PAAF also were examined. Plasma HGF levels were elevated in rats with two experimental pancreatitis models of different grades of severity. The degree of its elevation was correlated with the severity and the organ dysfunctions. In rats with severe pancreatitis, HGF protein and messenger RNA (mRNA) levels significantly increased in liver, kidney, and lung, which were injured organs. When anti-HGF neutralizing antibody was administered in severe pancreatitis, liver dysfunction worsened, and apoptotic cells increased in kidney. Recombinant HGF inhibited the cytocidal activity of PAAF on MDCK cells in a dose-dependent manner. Moreover, recombinant HGF prevented the apoptotic cell death (DNA fragmentation, nuclear fragmentation, and caspase-3 activation) induced by PAAF. These results suggest that HGF is produced in injured organs and may function as an organotrophic and antiapoptotic factor against the organ injuries in acute pancreatitis.

gSJ82s8w.title: A case of perforation of the small bowel due to a metastatic small intestinal tumor from pancreatic cancer -Analysis and report of this disease in Japan-

4xqANyxM.title: Involvement of peritoneal macrophage in the induction of cytotoxicity due to apoptosis in ascitic fluid associated with severe acute pancreatitis.
4xqANyxM.abstract: The aim of this study was to assess the significance of peritoneal macrophage in inducing cytotoxicity in ascitic fluid associated with severe acute pancreatitis. The involvement of peritoneal macrophage was examined experimentally in rats by macrophage depletion with peritoneal lavage prior to the development of pancreatitis. More than 94% of the cellular components collected from peritoneal cavities by the lavage are macrophages. Although the ascitic fluid collected from the rats with necrotizing pancreatitis showed cytocidal effects via apoptosis on Madin-Darby canine kidney cells in a dose- and time-dependent manner, cytotoxicity or apoptosis-inducing activity almost disappeared from the ascitic fluid by the preceding peritoneal lavage. The ascitic fluid did not show significant differences by the lavage in osmolarity and in concentrations of albumin, bilirubin, amylase, and lipase. Although a slight reduction of tumor necrosis factor-alpha was noted with the lavage, tumor necrosis factor-alpha failed to induce apoptotic cell death in the cells, and the neutralization by antibody ameliorated neither cell death nor apoptosis. We conclude that peritoneal macrophages secrete apoptosis-inducing factor(s) into pancreatitis-associated ascitic fluid, other than tumor necrosis factor-alpha.

M68IoQpV.title: Serum concentrations of 5-fluorouracil achieved with nocturnal constant-rate infusion in patients with disseminated cancer.
M68IoQpV.abstract: Nocturnal infusion of 5-fluorouracil (FUra) was performed in nine patients with disseminated cancer. Three gastric, three colon and three breast cancer patients were administered 300 mg/m2 FUra continuously for 10 h per day from 2100 h to 0700 h for more than 20 consecutive days. In the first three patients, who were treated by drip infusion without the use of a volumetric pump, serum FUra concentrations ranged widely, from 27 to 130 ng/ml, even though the rate of administration was re-adjusted four times during the night. The last six patients were treated using a volumetric pump, and FUra concentrations in serum ranged from 175 to 378 ng/ml, and displayed no circadian rhythm. Although the dose intensity and area under the curve of FUra in these patients were high, neither myelosuppression nor other side effects were observed.
